column1: To speak of the wonderful strides which the art of milling has taken during the past decade has become exceedingly trite. This progress
column2: patent to the most casual observer
column3: is a marked example of the power inherent in humanity to overcome natural obstacles. Had the climatic conditions of the Northwest allowed the raising of as good winter wheat as that raised in winter wheat sections generally
column4: I doubt if we should hear so much today of new processes and gradual reduction systems. So long as the great bulk of our supply of breadstuffs came from the winter wheat fields
column5: progress was very slow; the mills of 1860
column6: and I may even say of 1870
column8: so far as processes were concerned
column9: of those built half a century earlier. The reason for this lack of progress may be found in the ease with which winter wheat could be made into good
